judicious: marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters
unripened: not fully developed or mature; not ripe
unripe: not fully developed or mature; not ripe
thoughtless: without care or thought for others
strong: immune to attack; incapable of being tampered with
of good quality and condition; solidly built
having or wielding force or authority
having a strong physiological or chemical effect
being distilled rather than fermented; having a high alcoholic content
having strength or power greater than average or expected
of verbs not having standard (or regular) inflection
supine: passive as a result of indolence or indifference
early: at or near the beginning of a period of time or course of events or before the usual or expected time
being or occurring at an early stage of development
of an early stage in the development of a language or literature
superficial: hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough
concerned with or comprehending only what is apparent or obvious; not deep or penetrating emotionally or intellectually
occurring on or near the surface of the skin
unlucky: marked by or promising bad fortune
big: in an advanced stage of pregnancy
above average in size or number or quantity or magnitude or extent
insignificant: of little importance or influence or power; of minor status
devoid of importance, meaning, or force
young: (of crops) harvested at an early stage of development; before complete maturity
suggestive of youth; vigorous and fresh
(used of living things especially persons) in an early period of life or development or growth
not tried or tested by experience
cultivated: marked by refinement in taste and manners
no longer in the natural state; developed by human care and for human use
ambitious: requiring full use of your abilities or resources
having a strong desire for success or achievement
wise: evidencing the possession of inside information
marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters
having or prompted by wisdom or discernment
helpful: providing assistance or serving a useful function
pale: abnormally deficient in color as suggesting physical or emotional distress
(of light) lacking in intensity or brightness; dim or feeble
lacking in vitality or interest or effectiveness
very light colored; highly diluted with white
difficult: not easy; requiring great physical or mental effort to accomplish or comprehend or endure
canny: showing self-interest and shrewdness in dealing with others
pleasant: affording pleasure; being in harmony with your taste or likings
(of persons) having pleasing manners or behavior
considerate: showing concern for the rights and feelings of others
inventive: (used of persons or artifacts) marked by independence and creativity in thought or action
feeble: pathetically lacking in force or effectiveness
lacking bodily or muscular strength or vitality
unfair: not fair; marked by injustice or partiality or deception
smart: characterized by quickness and ease in learning
capable of independent and apparently intelligent action
showing mental alertness and calculation and resourcefulness
peculiar: beyond or deviating from the usual or expected
unique or specific to a person or thing or category
characteristic of one only; distinctive or special
contradictory: unable for both to exist or be true at the same time
that confounds or contradicts or confuses
of words or propositions so related that both cannot be true and both cannot be false
unenthusiastic: not enthusiastic; lacking excitement or ardor
caring: feeling and exhibiting concern and empathy for others
practical: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
being actually such in almost every respect
concerned with actual use or practice
having or put to a practical purpose or use
likeable: (of characters in literature or drama) evoking empathic or sympathetic feelings
civilized: having a high state of culture and development both social and technological
marked by refinement in taste and manners
clever: showing self-interest and shrewdness in dealing with others
ripe: fully developed or matured and ready to be eaten or used
most suitable or right for a particular purpose
at the highest point of development especially in judgment or knowledge
senseless: not marked by the use of reason
(of especially persons) lacking sense or understanding or judgment
serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being
unruffled: (of a body of water) free from disturbance by heavy waves
free from emotional agitation or nervous tension
philosophic: characterized by the attitude of a philosopher; meeting trouble with level-headed detachment
of or relating to philosophy or philosophers
serious: causing fear or anxiety by threatening great harm
concerned with work or important matters rather than play or trivialities
requiring effort or concentration; complex and not easy to answer or solve
undependable: not worthy of reliance or trust
liable to be erroneous or misleading
propitious: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
harmonious: exhibiting equivalence or correspondence among constituents of an entity or between different entities
unpleasant: offensive or disagreeable; causing discomfort or unhappiness
dirty: obtained illegally or by improper means
spreading pollution or contamination; especially radioactive contamination
soiled or likely to soil with dirt or grime
(of color) discolored by impurities; not bright and clear
expressing or revealing hostility or dislike
(of behavior or especially language) characterized by obscenity or indecency
puny: (used especially of persons) of inferior size
nice: socially or conventionally correct; refined or virtuous
pleasant or pleasing or agreeable in nature or appearance
uneager: lacking interest or spirit or animation
large: in an advanced stage of pregnancy
above average in size or number or quantity or magnitude or extent
fairly large or important in effect; influential
having broad power and range and scope
warm: characterized by liveliness or excitement or disagreement
having or producing a comfortable and agreeable degree of heat or imparting or maintaining heat
inducing the impression of warmth; used especially of reds and oranges and yellows when referring to color
of a seeker; near to the object sought
uncomfortable because of possible danger or trouble
heedless: marked by or paying little heed or attention
appealing: (of characters in literature or drama) evoking empathic or sympathetic feelings
able to attract interest or draw favorable attention
favorable: presaging or likely to bring good luck or a good outcome
(of winds or weather) tending to promote or facilitate
real: being or reflecting the essential or genuine character of something
capable of being treated as fact
having substance or capable of being treated as fact; not imaginary
being or occurring in fact or actuality; having verified existence; not illusory
no less than what is stated; worthy of the name
of, relating to, or representing an amount that is corrected for inflation
liberal: having political or social views favoring reform and progress
tolerant of change; not bound by authoritarianism, orthodoxy, or tradition
bold: very steep; having a prominent and almost vertical front
juvenile: displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
human: having human form or attributes as opposed to those of animals or divine beings
humorous: full of or characterized by humor
congenial: (used of plants) capable of cross-fertilization or of being grafted
sarcastic: expressing or expressive of ridicule that wounds
cowardly: lacking courage; ignobly timid and faint-hearted
sincere: characterized by a firm and humorless belief in the validity of your opinions
desperate: fraught with extreme danger; nearly hopeless
arising from or marked by despair or loss of hope
showing extreme courage; especially of actions courageously undertaken in desperation as a last resort
(of persons) dangerously reckless or violent as from urgency or despair
showing extreme urgency or intensity especially because of great need or desire
calm: (of weather) free from storm or wind
envious: showing extreme cupidity; painfully desirous of another's advantages
tenable: based on sound reasoning or evidence
slow: so lacking in interest as to cause mental weariness
slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity
not moving quickly; taking a comparatively long time
great: in an advanced stage of pregnancy
relatively large in size or number or extent; larger than others of its kind
remarkable or out of the ordinary in degree or magnitude or effect
bright: not made dim or less bright
likely to turn out well in the future
made smooth and bright by or as if by rubbing; reflecting a sheen or glow
characterized by quickness and ease in learning
emitting or reflecting light readily or in large amounts
having lots of light either natural or artificial
passive: peacefully resistant in response to injustice
expressing that the subject of the sentence is the patient of the action denoted by the verb
nasty: exasperatingly difficult to handle or circumvent
disgustingly dirty; filled or smeared with offensive matter
sizeable: large in amount or extent or degree
muted: being or made softer or less loud or clear
imaginative: (used of persons or artifacts) marked by independence and creativity in thought or action
honest: not disposed to cheat or defraud; not deceptive or fraudulent
gained or earned without cheating or stealing
irresponsible: showing lack of care for consequences
gallant: being attentive to women like an ideal knight
having or displaying great dignity or nobility
unsympathetic: (of characters in literature or drama) tending to evoke antipathetic feelings
not agreeing with your tastes or expectations
subdued: lacking in light; not bright or harsh
thick: hard to pass through because of dense growth
spoken as if with a thick tongue
having a short and solid form or stature
having component parts closely crowded together
not thin; of a specific thickness or of relatively great extent from one surface to the opposite usually in the smallest of the three solid dimensions
irrational: not consistent with or using reason
real but not expressible as the quotient of two integers
formative: forming or capable of forming or molding or fashioning
capable of forming new cells and tissues
talkative: friendly and open and willing to talk
stingy: deficient in amount or quality or extent
unwilling to spend (money, time, resources, etc.)
interested: involved in or affected by or having a claim to or share in
frail: easily broken or damaged or destroyed
wanting in moral strength, courage, or will; having the attributes of man as opposed to e.g. divine beings
forthright: characterized by directness in manner or speech; without subtlety or evasion
